title: 107_hr1812
content: The "School Anti-Violence Empowerment Act" authorizes grants for crisis intervention and school safety programs for students, staff, and facilities. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies on a competitive basis for hiring school counselors and enhancing school safety programs. Awards will be based on factors like the quality of violence prevention programs, need for crisis intervention counseling, and documented financial need. The Education Act of 1965 ensures equitable distribution of grants among different regions and areas. The Secretary may reserve up to 1% for administrative costs. Eligible local educational agencies can receive grants for hiring school counselors and enhancing school safety programs. SEC. 103. APPLICATIONS. Each local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant under this title, including a plan with details on existing safety programs, proposed changes, new programs, and financial need for enhancing school safety or hiring school counselors. The local educational agency must submit an application for a grant, including a plan for enhancing school safety or hiring school counselors, which requires documentation of financial need. Each local educational agency receiving a grant must provide an annual report to the Secretary. For agencies enhancing school safety programs, the report should detail fund usage and new safety measures. For agencies hiring school counselors, the report should outline fund usage and the number of counselors hired. For purposes of this title, "elementary school", "local educational agency", and "secondary school" have the same meanings as defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "school counselor" refers to an individual with documented competence in counseling children and adolescents in a school setting, possessing state licensure, national certification, or a minimum of a master's degree in school counseling. (C) requires a master's degree in school counseling from an accredited program. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. "School safety" pertains to protecting students, faculty, and school facilities from violence. SEC. 106. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $800,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2002-2006. TITLE II--INCREASED COPS FUNDING. SEC. 201. INCREASED FUNDING FOR THE COPS PROGRAM. $1,500,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2002-2006 for cooperative partnerships between schools and police departments. SEC. 202. GRANT AUTHORITY. SEC. 202. GRANT AUTHORITY. Section 1701 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended by removing subsection (k) and part of subsection (i). TITLE III--21ST CENTURY LEARNING. SEC. 301. AFTER-SCHOOL AND LIFE SKILLS PROGRAMS FOR AT-RISK YOUTH. Section 10907 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate $950,000,000 annually for after-school programs from 2002 to 2006. TITLE IV--MODEL PROGRAM AND CLEARINGHOUSE. SEC. 401. MODEL PROGRAM. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Attorney General, will develop a model violence prevention program for local educational agencies within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. Additionally, a national clearinghouse will be established to provide technical assistance on alternative violence prevention programs to local educational agencies.
